title: Day 23 – Clifty Falls State Park, IN to Louisville, KY
content:
Rain and coffee cake. We opened the back hatch of their car and made a makeshift not-so-dry breakfast table and made coffee and tea. Emily’s last-minute coffee cake was heaven, and I had to try it from every corner of the pan to ensure its high quality. Around 9am the rain stopped, which was perfect timing for tent breakdown. A final selfie and thank-yous to Emily and Jim, and we zoomed away towards Louisville.

This morning’s roads gave yesterday’s a run for their money. Picture-perfect country lanes with only churchgoers on the road, punctuated every so often with a Trump sign or Confederate flag.

In the small town of New Washington we stopped for sustenance outside a closed grocery store. There we met a very affectionate stray cat we fondly named Cuthbert. Tess gave him a little half-and-half.

After New Washington it got really hilly - we were almost always on an up or a down. I considered this good training for the hillier terrain to come in Illinois and Missouri. Fortunately my knee wasn’t giving me any issues.

After another pit stop in Charleston, we pushed on towards the river. The Underground Railroad trail had us going along the river for quite a ways approaching Louisville, but we were stymied by the closure of the bike path.

The alternate routing provided by Google was a little shorter and took us on roads with huge shoulders so it turned out fine. When we entered Jeffersonville we started seeing Biden signs and knew we were getting close to the city.

We crossed the Ohio River on the massive pedestrian-only Big Four Bridge, which was busy with Sunday traffic. It offered us our first view of downtown Louisville.

Bike lanes brought us the short distance to the Highlands neighborhood where we had our Airbnb, purchased with a gift card I’d received from Tess’ mom for my birthday. Thanks Bev! We passed dozens of restaurants on the way, and our hunger quickly grew. A detour came up a few blocks away and we noped our way right through it.

Our Airbnb is nestled on Baxter Avenue, filled with cool bars and restaurants. We were blown away by the size and quality of the place, which looked even better than the pictures. We inhaled some cheese sticks and a granola bar, showered and explored the private roof patio - with a view of downtown! We felt massively spoiled, but pushed that thought out of our minds. We biked to Louisville…we deserve this!

After a nap we dazedly wandered to Agave and Rye for dinner (“welcome to Agave and Rye - how can we make your night epic?”). We had a trio of grilled vegetable tacos, a faux-chicken General Tso taco, and a spicy fish taco. Tess had a bourbon peach drink that was so strong she had to dilute it with a ginger beer. On our way back to the Airbnb we stopped at Baxter Jack’s Volleyball Club, a bar and club where a tournament was underway.

We wound down with Netflix in our living room and I caught up with the blog. Before bed we stole a last look at the lit-up Louisville skyline from the patio.
